McGonigle v. Boston, (cases interpreting.raw_text: McGonigle v. Boston, (cases interpreting reasonable care of proprietors)
McGonigle v. Boston, (cases interpreting.proposition: The duty of care owed by possessors of land to invitees is well-established under Massachusetts law and general tort principles: proprietors must exercise reasonable care to keep the premises safe and warn invitees of nonobvious dangers, and may be liable for injuries caused by foreseeable dangerous conditions.

Steir v. Girl Scouts of U.S.A., 394 Mass.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a dissenting opinion in a criminal case discussing jury instructions on malice aforethought in a murder prosecution. It does not address negligence, duty to supervise, foreseeability of hazards, or reliance on statutes, restatements, or Massachusetts tort authorities for civil negligence claims. Therefore it does not support the proposition for which it is being cited in this context.
Steir v. Girl Scouts of U.S.A., 394 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "A fundamental proposition of our system of criminal justice is that a defendant cannot be convicted of a crime absent a proper instruction to the jury on the elements of the crime with which he stands charged. The duty to instruct properly falls on the trial judge. Commonwealth v. Porter, 10 Met. 263, 285-286 (1845)."

Smith v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth..raw_text: Smith v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 381 Mass. 172 (1980)
Smith v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth..proposition: Plaintiff expressly invokes the following statutes, restatements, and Massachusetts authorities as relevant legal support for his claims of negligence and the relief sought herein (non-exhaustive list):
Smith v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth..support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about sufficiency of the evidence for second-degree murder and joint enterprise, not a civil negligence action. It does not discuss negligence standards, civil liability, relief in tort, or cite statutes/restatements relevant to negligence claims. Therefore it does not provide legal support for a plaintiff’s negligence claims or related relief in a civil context.
Smith v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth..relevant_excerpt: “Murder in the second degree is an unlawful killing with malice aforethought; malice includes any intent to inflict injury on another without legal excuse or palliation… After considering the pattern of harassment of the movers… the jury could have inferred that the shots were the product of an intent to inflict injury without excuse and were fired with the knowledge that there was a strong likelihood that someone would be killed. Thus, the evidence was sufficient to permit the jury to infer the existence of the essential elements of murder in the second degree.”
